questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with paronychia, as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paronychia is an infection of the nail fold, presenting with redness, swelling, tenderness, and pus formation.
  • Acute paronychia is most often bacterial, caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) provides coverage against Gram-positive organisms and anaerobes, making it the drug of choice for acute bacterial paronychia.
  • Along with antibiotics, if pus is present, incision and drainage may be required.

Paronychia:

  • Acute paronychia:
    • Cause: Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus.
    • Onset: Rapid, painful swelling with pus.
    • Treatment: Drainage (if abscess) + Amoxiclav.
  • Chronic paronychia:
    • Cause: Candida albicans most common.
    • Onset: Gradual swelling, less painful, usually without pus.
    • Treatment: Antifungals (eg, topical clotrimazole, oral fluconazole in resistant cases).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Metronidazole (Option B): Effective against anaerobes and protozoa but not first-line for Staphylococcus or Streptococcus, which are the main causative organisms.

Amikacin (Option C): An aminoglycoside targeting Gram-negative bacilli. It is not effective against the Gram-positive organisms commonly responsible for paronychia.

Norfloxacin (Option D): A fluoroquinolone with poor coverage against Staphylococcus aureus. It is not recommended for soft tissue infections like paronychia.

Key Takeaway:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the treatment of choice for acute paronychia because it provides broad coverage against the most common causative bacteria. Chronic paronychia, however, requires antifungal therapy since Candida is the usual culprit.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot of a farmer that appeared after a minor injury, with microscope revealing copper penny bodies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hallmark feature here is the presence of copper penny bodies (Medlar bodies) on microscopy, which are pathognomonic for chromoblastomycosis.
  • Clinically, the disease presents as a slow-growing, cauliflower-like verrucous lesion, typically on exposed areas like the feet after trauma with contaminated soil or vegetation.
  • It commonly affects farmers and individuals exposed to rural environments.

Chromoblastomycosis:

  • Causative organisms: Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora, Phialophora.
  • Risk factor: Minor trauma in agricultural workers.
  • Clinical appearance: Verrucous, cauliflower-like lesions that spread slowly but can become disfiguring if untreated.
  • Microscopy: Thick-walled, pigmented fungal cells called Medlar bodies or copper penny bodies.
  • Spread: Chronic, localized; lymphatic spread is uncommon.
  • Treatment: Prolonged antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine; surgical excision for localized severe disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Blastomycosis (Option B): Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. Typically presents with pulmonary infection or ulcerative skin lesions. It does not produce verrucous cauliflower-like growths or Medlar bodies.

Sporotrichosis (Option C): Known as "rose gardener's disease," caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Characterized by nodular lesions spreading along lymphatic channels. It does not produce localized cauliflower-like masses or copper penny bodies.

Phaeohyphomycosis (Option D): Caused by dematiaceous fungi (darkly pigmented), but histology shows pigmented septate hyphae, not Medlar bodies. Clinical presentation is variable but not typically cauliflower-shaped verrucous growths.

Key Takeaway:

A cauliflower-shaped verrucous lesion on the foot of a farmer with copper penny bodies on microscopy is diagnostic of chromoblastomycosis. It is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis caused by pigmented fungi, managed with prolonged antifungal therapy and, in some cases, surgery.

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer presents with swelling on foot and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Granules from the discharge were examined under the microscope, shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presentation described-chronic swelling of the foot, multiple discharging sinuses, and granules in pus-is typical of mycetoma.
  • Farmers and agricultural workers are commonly affected due to repeated trauma with soil contamination.
  • Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria (Actinomycetoma) and fungi (Eumycetoma), making option A correct.
  • The granules seen under microscopy are diagnostic clues, with color varying by causative organism.

Mycetoma:

  • Actinomycetoma (bacterial):
    • Causative agents: Actinomyces, Nocardia.
    • Granule colors: white, yellow, or red.
    • Treatment: Long-term antibiotics.
  • Eumycetoma (fungal):
    • Causative agents: Madurella, Exophiala.
    • Granule colors: black or brown.
    • Treatment: Antifungal agents and sometimes surgical excision.
  • Pathology: Progressive granulomatous infection with discharging sinuses, leading to deep tissue and even bone involvement.
  • Spread: Direct extension and hematogenous spread, but not lymphatic.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Undergoes lymphatic spread (Option B): Incorrect because mycetoma does not spread via lymphatics. It spreads by direct extension and hematogenous routes.

There is lymphocyte accumulation (Option C): Incorrect because mycetoma is a granulomatous disease characterized by neutrophils, macrophages, and giant cells rather than predominantly lymphocyte infiltration.

Involves only superficial tissues (Option D): Incorrect because mycetoma progressively extends into subcutaneous tissue, fascia, muscle, and bone, causing chronic deformity and disability if untreated.

Key Takeaway:

Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by swelling, discharging sinuses, and granules. It can be caused by both bacteria (actinomycetoma) and fungi (eumycetoma), which spreads by direct extension, and involves deep tissues including bone.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple anogenital warts. The biopsy of these lesions showed squamous atypia. Which of the following human papillomavirus types are considered high-risk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image and history indicate condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts), most caused by HPV types 6 and 11.
  • The biopsy showing squamous atypia raises concern for progression to high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) or malignancy, which is associated with high-risk HPV types.
  • Among the listed options, HPV 18 is a high-risk oncogenic strain. Along with HPV 16, it is strongly linked to cervical, anal, penile, vulvar, and oropharyngeal cancers.
  • HPV 18 is particularly associated with cervical adenocarcinoma.

HPV and oncogenic potential:

  • Low-risk types (HPV 6, 11): Cause benign anogenital warts and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.
  • High-risk types (HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 45): Cause cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cancers of the cervix, vulva, anus, penis, and oropharynx.
  • HPV 2: Associated with common cutaneous warts (verruca vulgaris), not anogenital warts.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

HPV 2 (Option A): Causes common skin warts (verruca vulgaris). It is not linked to anogenital warts or malignancy.

HPV 6 (Option C): A low-risk HPV type causing benign anogenital warts. It does not carry malignant potential.

HPV 11 (Option D): Another low-risk type, associated with genital warts and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis. It is not linked to cancer.

Key Takeaway:

HPV types 16 and 18 are the most important high-risk oncogenic strains, associated with cervical and other anogenital cancers. In contrast, HPV types 6 and 11 are low-risk and cause benign genital warts. Biopsy showing atypia in genital lesions should raise suspicion for infection with a high-risk strain such as HPV 18.

questions.text: Which type of alopecia is commonly associated with inflammatory alopecia in a 30-year-old male patient who presents with tinea capitis infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tinea capitis is a superficial fungal infection of the scalp caused by dermatophytes (Trichophyton and Microsporum species).
  • While ectothrix and endothrix types typically cause non-inflammatory alopecia, Favus and Kerion are the inflammatory variants associated with scarring alopecia.
  • Kerion:
    • Caused by Trichophyton verrucosum (often zoonotic, eg, cattle).
    • Severe inflammatory reaction with boggy, tender swelling, pustules, abscesses, and hair loss.
    • May cause patchy scarring alopecia if untreated.
  • Favus:
    • Caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.
    • Chronic infection leading to yellow cup-shaped crusts (scutula).
    • Produces a honeycomb appearance and results in permanent scarring alopecia.

Types of Tinea Capitis and Alopecia Patterns

Endothrix and Favus (Option A): Endothrix infections are non-inflammatory and do not typically cause scarring. Favus is inflammatory, but this pair is partially correct, not fully.

Ectothrix and Endothrix (Option B): Both are non-inflammatory forms, producing hair breakage but not scarring alopecia.

Kerion and Endothrix (Option D): Kerion is inflammatory, but Endothrix is not. Hence, this combination is incorrect.

Key Takeaway:

The inflammatory forms of tinea capitis associated with scarring alopecia are Favus and Kerion. Early recognition and treatment with systemic antifungals (eg, griseofulvin, terbinafine) are essential to prevent permanent hair loss.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with an itchy rash on his thigh. He gave a history of using topical corticosteroids a few days back, which gave him temporary relief. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tinea incognito is a type of dermatophyte infection modified by corticosteroid (systemic or topical) and other immunosuppressive agents.

Tinea incognito

  • Ringworm infection altered by systemic or topical corticosteroids, often prescribed for another condition or misdiagnosed as eczema, is called tinea incognito due to its disguised appearance.

Pathophysiology:

  • Corticosteroids suppress local inflammation and immune response, masking typical ringworm signs.
  • They also reduce cell-mediated immunity, allowing fungal growth to continue unchecked.

Clinical Features

  • Patients often report initial relief from itching and redness.
  • Symptoms recur after stopping steroids, and reapplication brings temporary relief, creating a treatment cycle.
  • Presentation:
    • The characteristic raised, scaly border disappears.
    • Appearance includes nondescript nodules, brownish discolouration, and minimal inflammation.
    • On the face, it may mimic perioral dermatitis (papules and pustules); on the eyelids, it can resemble a stye.
    • Chronic use may cause skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and striae in the groins or underarms.
    • Even mild steroids (like 1% hydrocortisone) can significantly alter the presentation.

Management

  • Oral antifungals (e.g., terbinafine, itraconazole) are recommended rather than topical agents alone.
  • Continue low-potency topical steroids (e.g., 1% hydrocortisone) temporarily to ease symptoms while antifungals take effect.
  • Advise patients about possible symptom rebound and the importance of steroid discontinuation.
  • Arrange follow-up to confirm steroids have stopped and the infection is fully resolved.

Tinea corporis (Option A), commonly referred to as ringworm, is a superficial fungal infection of the skin caused by dermatophytes from the Trichophyton, Epidermophyton, or Microsporum genera. It typically presents with itching and may become extensive or merge into larger patches, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems.

Tinea cruris (Options B) or jock itch, is a fungal infection affecting the skin of the groin, pubic region, perineum, and perianal area, caused by dermatophyte fungi. Patients typically present with an itchy rash localised to the groin area.

questions.text: Identify the disorder in which the following clinical picture is seen:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) is a rare chronic papulosquamous disorder characterised by follicular papules and sharply demarcated islands of sparing.

Definition:

PRP is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disorder affecting both children and adults. Shows a cephalocaudal spread with characteristic clinical features.

Clinical Features:

  • Initial presentation: Diffuse fine scaling on the scalp.
  • Progression: Papules coalesce into plaques that spread in a cephalocaudal manner.
  • Classic hallmark: Orange-red follicular hyperkeratotic papules with intervening normal skin - described as "islands of sparing".
  • May evolve into generalised erythroderma.
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma: Red-orange thickening of palms and soles - described as "sandal-like PPK".
  • Nail changes: Thickening, discolouration, and subungual hyperkeratosis may occur.
  • Juvenile classic PRP often resolves spontaneously.

Pathology & Investigations (Histology):

  • Epidermis: Alternating horizontal and vertical orthokeratosis and parakeratosis (checkerboard pattern).
  • Hair follicles: Follicular plugging and irregular acanthosis.
  • Dermis: Sparse superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.
  • These histopathological findings help distinguish PRP from psoriasis and eczema.

Explanation of other options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Characterised by silvery-white scales and symmetrical plaques; lacks follicular accentuation and islands of sparing.

Eczema (Option B): Typically vesicular in acute stages, with crusting and oozing, not follicular-based or progressing to erythroderma.

Lichen nitidus (Option C): Tiny, flat-topped, shiny papules; not associated with cephalocaudal spread, palmoplantar keratoderma, or islands of sparing.

Key Takeaway:

Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a chronic dermatosis present with orange-red follicular papules, islands of sparing, cephalocaudal progression, and waxy palmoplantar keratoderma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with fever, sore throat, malaise and vesicles on the hands, feet, and painful oral ulcers. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness usually affecting infants and children under 10 years.
  • HFMD involves the hands, feet, and mouth. Vesicles are surrounded by a thin halo of erythema, eventually rupturing and forming superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base and erythematous rim.
  • Cause: MC - coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus71 in most cases, many other strains of coxsackievirus.
  • Spread - oral ingestion of the shed virus from the gastrointestinal or upper respiratory tract of infected hosts or via vesicle fluid or oral secretions.
  • Treatment is mostly supportive and symptomatic. In severe cases, if neurological complications occur, intravenous immunoglobulin is advisable.

Explanation of other options:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1)(Option A) can cause herpetic gingivostomatitis, which affects the mouth only, no rash on hands/feet.
  • Parvovirus B19 infection(Option B): Causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), not HFMD. Presents with a "slapped cheek" rash and lacy exanthem on the trunk and limbs.
  • Epstein-Barr virus infection(Option D): Causes infectious mononucleosis, with pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, but no vesicular rash on hands/feet.

questions.text: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is associated with all of the following infections except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Syphilis is not associated with Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (FHCS) is perihepatitis associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

  • It most commonly occurs as a complication of PID caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. (Options B & C ruled out)
  • It presents with right upper quadrant pain due to inflammation of the liver capsule (not the parenchyma), often with "violin string" adhesions between the liver capsule and anterior abdominal wall.
  • Genital tuberculosis may rarely cause similar perihepatic adhesions. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diagnosis: Laparoscopy (gold standard) shows violin-string adhesions.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 50-year-old smoker presenting with a painless oral lesion accompanied by a white patch in the mouth, as shown in the given image, after seeking medical care?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image demonstrates a distinct white patch on the tongue, which, together with the history of smoking, is indicative of leukoplakia.

  • Leukoplakia is a precancerous condition closely linked to prolonged tobacco use and smoking.
  • It develops due to persistent irritation, which can cause hyperkeratosis and, in advanced cases, progress to dysplasia.

Features of Leukoplakia:


Explanations of other options:

Candidiasis (Option B): Oral candidiasis (thrush) appears as white patches that can be scraped off, leaving behind red, inflamed mucosa.

Lichen planus (Option C): Lichen planus typically presents with a reticular, lace-like pattern (Wickham's striae) and can sometimes be painful or erosive.

Oral cancer (Option D): Oral cancer usually appears as a painful, ulcerated, and indurated growth that may bleed, whereas leukoplakia typically starts as a painless lesion.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image depicts warty lesions in the anogenital region suggestive of condyloma acuminata.

  • Genital warts (condyloma acuminata) are caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly strains 6 and 11.
  • Characteristic features include:
  • Raised, verrucous, cauliflower-shaped growths in the genital or anal area
  • Lesions may be pink, skin-toned, or hyperkeratotic
  • Typically painless and develops gradually
  • Spread is usually through sexual contact

Explanations of other options:

Bowen disease (Option B): Bowen’s disease appears as a sharply defined, reddish, scaly patch and represents a carcinoma in situ.

Condyloma lata (Option C): Condyloma lata manifests as wide, flat, and moist growths typically associated with secondary syphilis.

Haemorrhoids (Option D): Haemorrhoids appear as engorged, bluish, and painful venous swellings rather than warty lesions.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC145302/

questions.text: Which of the following features in an 18-year-old female would suggest the initial stage of this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts acne vulgaris, a frequent skin disorder in which the primary lesions are comedones.

  • Comedones (blackheads and whiteheads) are the initial lesions of acne vulgaris, often seen in adolescents because of hormonal influences.
  • The condition begins when hair follicles become blocked with sebum and keratin, resulting in comedone formation.
  • Types of Comedones:
    • Open comedone (blackhead): Appears dark due to melanin oxidation.
    • Closed comedone (whitehead): Remains covered by skin, giving it a flesh-colored look.

Acne Progression Stages and Lesions:


Explanation of other options:

Papule (Option A): This is incorrect since papules appear at a later stage when comedones undergo inflammation.

Pustule (Option B): This is incorrect as pustules are filled with pus and arise during the inflammatory stage.

Abscess (Option C): Incorrect because abscesses are seen in severe acne (nodulocystic acne), not the primary stage.

questions.text: A dermatologist is performing a diagnostic skin examination using a Wood's lamp to evaluate a patient with suspected fungal and pigmentary disorders.What is the wavelength of light produced by the Wood's lamp?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A traditional Wood's lamp is a low-output mercury arc lamp covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide).
  • It emits ultraviolet light in the range of 320-450 nm, with a peak wavelength around 365 nm (often approximated to 360 nm).
  • The Wood's lamp is primarily used in dermatology to diagnose fungal infections, pigmentary disorders, and bacterial infections by causing fluorescence of certain substances.
  • Invented in 1903 by Robert W. Wood, a Baltimore physicist.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • 320 nm (Option A): Falls into the UV-B range and is not the peak emission wavelength of a Wood's lamp.
  • 400 nm (Option C): Closer to visible violet light; does not fall within the effective diagnostic range of the Wood's lamp.
  • 480 nm (Option D): Belongs to the visible spectrum (blue light) and is too long to be used effectively for Wood's lamp diagnostic purposes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with flaccid bullae over the face and neck. The blisters rupture easily, and the lesions spread when gentle pressure is applied (positive Nikolsky sign). The patient also has oral mucosal involvement.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is characterized by flaccid bullae that rupture easily, typical of intraepidermal blistering caused by acantholysis (loss of keratinocyte adhesion).
  • Positive Nikolsky sign (epidermis shears off by gentle rubbing) and Asboe-Hansen sign (blister spreading when pressure is applied) are hallmark features of PV.
  • Common sites: face, scalp, trunk, neck, and oral mucosa involvement is a distinctive feature.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Auto-IgG against desmoglein-3 (± desmoglein-1) in desmosomes → suprabasal split.
    • Histology: Suprabasal acantholysis with 'row of tombstones' basal keratinocytes.
    • Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Intercellular 'fishnet' pattern of IgG and C3.
    • Tzanck smear: Presence of acantholytic cells.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Bullous pemphigoid (Option A):
    • Blisters are tense, pruritic, and on an urticarial base.
    • Nikolsky sign is negative or weak.
    • No mucosal involvement (rare).
    • Histology: Subepidermal split with linear IgG and C3 along basement membrane (BP180/BP230).
  • Pemphigus foliaceus (Option C):
    • Presents with superficial crusted erosions without mucosal involvement.
    • Split level is subcorneal, and autoantibodies target desmoglein-1.
    • Typical sites: Seborrheic areas (face, scalp).
    • Can be confused with 'Pemphigus violaceous', but violaceous is not the correct term.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option D):
    • Characterized by tiny grouped vesicles with severe itching.
    • Negative Nikolsky sign.
    • No mucosal involvement.
    • DIF shows granular IgA deposits in dermal papillae.
    • Strong association with celiac disease.

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient presents with a lesion over the face. Histopathological examination reveals peripheral palisading cells and basaloid cells in nests or cords, along with clefting artifact between the tumor nests and surrounding stroma.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC):
    • Most common skin tumor.
    • No premalignant lesion.
    • Slow-growing but locally aggressive, with metastasis rate <1%.
    • Histopathology:
      • Basaloid cells arranged in nests or cords.
      • Peripheral palisading (nuclei aligned at the periphery of tumor nests).
      • Clefting artifact between tumor nests and stroma.
    • Treatment options:
      • Topical agents: 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU), Imiquimod.
      • Mohs Micrographic Surgery (MMS): gold standard for high-risk lesions.
      • Sonic hedgehog pathway inhibitors: Vismodegib, Sonidegib.
    • Associated syndrome:
      • Gorlin syndrome (Nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome)- PTCH gene mutation causing multiple BCCs.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): Characterized by keratin pearls and intercellular bridges histologically, not peripheral palisading cells.
  • Malignant melanoma (Option C): Melanoma shows atypical melanocytes, prominent nucleoli, and melanin pigment, not basaloid nests or peripheral palisading.
  • Seborrhoeic keratosis (Option D): Benign epidermal lesion with keratin-filled cysts ('horn cysts'), not malignant features or peripheral palisading.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with excessive hair fall. She has recently started treatment for breast cancer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rapid onset of diffuse hair loss within 1-3 weeks after starting treatment for Breast cancer, is classic for Anagen Effluvium, a form of non-scarring alopecia, most often triggered by Chemotherapeutic drugs. These drugs damage rapidly proliferating hair matrix cells, leading to fragile, dystrophic anagen hairs.

Explanation for incorrect option:

Telogen effluvium (Option A): Premature shift from anagen to telogen due to systemic stress, Usually occurs 3 months after the stressor.

Alopecia totalis (Option B): Complete loss of scalp hair. Typically autoimmune, not triggered by chemotherapy or systemic illness.

Androgenetic alopecia (Option D): Patterned hair loss (frontal hairline recession and vertex thinning), chronic progressive, unrelated to acute triggers like chemotherapy.

choices.text: Polycystic ovary disease, Obesity, Oral Contraceptive Pills
Polycystic ovary disease, Obesity, Oral Contraceptive Pills, Hemochromatosis, Addison's disease

questions.text: A patient presents with hyperpigmented, velvety thickened plaques over the skin (as shown in the image).Which of the following are associated with this skin condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows Acanthosis Nigricans:
    • Characterized by hyperpigmented, velvety, thickened skin plaques, usually in body folds (neck, axilla).
    • Pathophysiology:
      • Keratinocyte hyperproliferation due to increased Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1) or insulin levels.
    • Histopathology:
      • Hyperkeratosis.
  • Associations:
    • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOS) → linked via insulin resistance.
    • Obesity → leads to hyperinsulinemia → promotes keratinocyte proliferation.
    • Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCP) → hormonal modulation can contribute.
    • HAIR-AN Syndrome (Hyperandrogenism, Insulin Resistance, and Acanthosis Nigricans).
    • Malignancies (especially gastric adenocarcinoma) → Paraneoplastic acanthosis nigricans.
  • Other Conditions:
    • Hemochromatosis and Addison's disease are not classically associated with acanthosis nigricans.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Polycystic ovary disease + Obesity (Option A):
    • Incomplete, misses Oral Contraceptive Pills as an important association.
  • Obesity + Hemochromatosis (Option C):
    • Hemochromatosis is not a known association.
  • All the above (Option D):
    • Hemochromatosis and Addison's disease are not standard associations with acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text: A farmer presented with the following swelling on foot with discharging sinus. What diagnosis do you suspect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Madura foot also known as Mycetoma, an uncommon chronic infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues in tropical countries is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains --------(Choice A)

Option B- Chromoblastomycosis (Verrucous dermatitis)

Clinical feature : Rough warty, cauliflower like lesions over exposed (trauma prone) sites . MC on foot

Choice C- Sporotrichosis

The characteristic infection involves suppurating subcutaneous nodules that progress proximally along lymphatic channels (lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis).

Choice D- Pheohyphomycosis:

Clinical syndromes include invasive sinusitis, sometimes with bone necrosis, as well as subcutaneous nodules or abscesses, keratitis, lung masses, osteomyelitis, mycotic arthritis, endocarditis, brain abscess, and disseminated infection.

questions.text: A 12-year old male presented with asymptomatic erythematous scaly lesions over back. There was history of sore throat. There were collarette scales in erythematous lesions. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting.
  • Flu-like symptoms a few days before the rash appears. First lesion is characterised by a large circular or oval "herald patch", usually found on the chest, abdomen, or back.
  • The herald patch is followed by the development of smaller scaly oval red patches, resembling a Christmas tree, distributed mainly on the chest and back.
  • Collarette scale is characteristic sign in pityriasis rosea. With edge peripherally attached and lifted up near the centre of lesion.

Option B- Pityriasis rubra pilaris Scaly (Pityriasis), Pink to orange (Rubra), Follicular papules (pilaris), Grouped papules frequently coalesce to form large plaques, typically with distinct islands of normal skin and islands of normal skin are often studded with erythematous follicular scaly papules. Palm and sole are commonly involved with orange red waxy keratoderma.

Option C- Pityriasis versicolor is a superficial fungal infection. There are hypo or hyperpigmented mildly scaly macules over neck,upper chest, upper back.

Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur

On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'sphagetti and meatball appearance'

On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Option D- Guttate psoriasis

It is a variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults.

Manifests as numerous, small, scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as "drop-like" and typically manifest as 2 to 6 mm papules.

questions.text: A patient presented with hypopigmented rash with satellite lesions as shown in the image. What will be the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is a case of BT leprosy

Hypopigmented patch with satellite lesions are characteristic of BT leprosy

Option D- In TT leprosy there will be hypopigmented patch without satellite lesions

Option B- In BL leprosy there will be multiple lesions which tends to be symmetrical in presentation

Option C- In LL Leprosy there will be multiple lesions in symmetrical manner.

questions.text: What skin condition is characterized by the presence of coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Etiological agent: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Lesions of erythrasma are asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented. Occurs in axilla, groin or inframammary area.

Colors on woods lamp:

  • Erythrasma- Coral red
  • Versicolor- Yellow
  • Tinea capitis(Microsporum sp.)- Blue-Green
  • Tinea capitis( T. schoenleinii)- Dull blue
  • Vitiligo- Chalky white

Option B, C and D do not show fluorescence on wood's lamp examination.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with thickened, discolored toenails. Fungal culture confirms onychomycosis. The dermatologist prescribes a topical agent from the morpholine class in the form of a nail lacquer. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amorolfine is a morpholine antifungal used topically as a nail lacquer for treating onychomycosis.

Amorolfine:

  • Class: Belongs to the morpholine class of antifungal agents.
  • Formulation: Available as a 5% nail lacquer used for the topical treatment of onychomycosis.
  • Mechanism of Action: Inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis, targeting dermatophytes and yeasts.
  • Indications:
    • White superficial onychomycosis
    • Distal subungual onychomycosis (limited to distal nail of a few digits)
    • Used as monotherapy or as adjunctive therapy in more extensive disease
    • Also helpful for secondary prophylaxis in chronic/recurrent cases
  • Application Frequency: Once weekly application
  • Transungual Penetration:
    • Upon solvent evaporation, the drug concentration increases to 25%, enhancing nail plate diffusion
  • Effectiveness:
    • Achieves clinical response in approximately 50% of cases when used alone for mild distal subungual onychomycosis

Explanation of other options:

Oxiconazole (Option B): An imidazole antifungal, typically used in cream formulations for superficial fungal infections like tinea corporis. It is not used as a nail lacquer.

Ciclopirox olamine (Option C): An effective topical antifungal available as an 8% nail lacquer for onychomycosis, but it belongs to the hydroxypyridone class, not the morpholine class specified in the question.

Tioconazole (Option D): An imidazole antifungal, used mainly in topical treatments for cutaneous or vaginal candidiasis, but not commonly used as a nail lacquer.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1532336/
  2. https://ijdvl.com/current-treatment-of-onychomycosis/#

questions.text: A newborn is admitted to the NICU shortly after birth due to thick, armor-like skin covering the entire body. On examination, the baby has ectropion, eclabium, contractures of the limbs, and deep fissures in the skin. The baby was born encased in a tight, shiny membrane, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of thick hyperkeratotic skin plates, deep fissures, ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory distress in a newborn point towards a diagnosis of Harlequin ichthyosis.

Harlequin Ichthyosis:

  • Rare, life-threatening autosomal recessive skin disorder present at birth
  • Caused by mutations in the ABCA12 gene, impairing lipid transport essential for skin barrier function
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Defective lipid transport disrupts the epidermal barrier
    • Leads to massive hyperkeratosis, fluid loss, risk of infection, and impaired thermoregulation
  • Clinical Features:
    • Thick, plate-like ("armor-like") scales forming over the body
    • Ectropion (eyelids turned outward), eclabium (lips turned outward)
    • Contractures of digits, with underdeveloped fingers and toes
    • High risk for dehydration, secondary infections, and respiratory compromise
    • Delayed desquamation, with gradual improvement but requiring lifelong skin care
  • Diagnosis:
    • Primarily clinical, based on classic appearance at birth
    • Genetic testing confirms ABCA12 mutation
    • Skin biopsy is rarely needed; shows marked hyperkeratosis
  • Management:
    • NICU care with focus on hydration, temperature control, and infection prevention
    • Regular use of moisturizers and keratolytics (e.g., petrolatum, urea, lactic acid)
    • Oral retinoids (e.g., acitretin or isotretinoin) can reduce keratin buildup
    • Treat infections early with systemic antibiotics
    • Lifelong supportive skin care and dermatology follow-up

Explanation of other options:

Lamellar ichthyosis (Option B): Often presents at birth with a collodion membrane, followed by large, thick, dark scales over the body. Unlike harlequin ichthyosis, it lacks severe contractures, ectropion, eclabium, and deep fissures.

Bathing suit ichthyosis (Option C): A rare variant of lamellar ichthyosis where scaling predominantly affects the trunk and proximal limbs in a distribution resembling a bathing suit.

Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option D): A mild, common inherited skin condition with fine white or gray scaling, usually starting in early childhood and affecting extensor surfaces, not present at birth.

References:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562318/

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with intensely itchy eczematous plaques over her abdomen and limbs. She reports the rash has worsened over the last few weeks. A skin biopsy reveals a subepidermal blister, and direct immunofluorescence demonstrates linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of pruritic eczematous plaques, subepidermal cleft on biopsy, and linear IgG and C3 deposition on immunofluorescence strongly indicate bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous Pemphigoid:

  • Common subepidermal autoimmune blistering disorder
  • Predominantly affects the elderly
  • Autoantibodies are directed against hemidesmosomal proteins:
    • BP230 (BPAG1)
    • BP180 (BPAG2)
  • Clinical Stages:
    1. Prodromal (non-bullous) phase:
      • Presents with itchy, eczematous or urticarial plaques
    2. Bullous phase:
      • Tense vesicles and bullae on erythematous or normal skin
      • Intense pruritus
      • Blisters may rupture to form hemorrhagic or yellow crusts
      • Healing without scarring
      • Oral lesions may occasionally occur
  • Diagnostic Features:
    • Histopathology:
      • Subepidermal split with eosinophil-rich inflammatory infiltrate
    • Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF):
      • Linear IgG and C3 deposition along the dermoepidermal junction
    • Antibody involved: IgG
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Nikolsky sign: Negative
    • Bulla spread sign: Positive
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: Topical and systemic corticosteroids
    • Immunosuppressive agents may be added in severe/refractory cases

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A): This shows intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis and presents with intercellular IgG deposits on immunofluorescence ("fishnet pattern"), not the linear basement membrane staining seen here.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option C): Characterized by grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces and associated with celiac disease, it shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, not linear IgG and C3.

Pemphigus foliaceus (Option D): This is a superficial blistering disorder affecting the upper epidermis; immunofluorescence shows intercellular IgG without subepidermal cleft or linear basement membrane staining.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and difficulty getting up from the floor. On examination, reddish, scaly plaques are observed over the knuckles, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of violaceous, scaly papules over the extensor surfaces of the MCP and PIP joints is characteristic of Gottron's papules, a hallmark of juvenile dermatomyositis, especially in a child with fever and muscle weakness.

Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM):

  • A rare autoimmune inflammatory myopathy primarily affecting children
  • Involves both skin and proximal muscles
  • Clinical Features:
    • Muscle Weakness:
      • Predominantly proximal (e.g., difficulty in climbing stairs, rising from a chair, or lifting arms to comb hair)
    • Characteristic Skin Findings:
      • Gottron's papules: Red or violaceous, scaly plaques over knuckles, elbows, knees

      • Heliotrope rash: Purple discoloration with or without swelling of upper eyelids

    • Systemic Symptoms:
      • May include fever, fatigue, malaise, and arthralgia or arthritis
  • Investigations:
    • Muscle Enzymes:
      • Elevated creatine kinase (CK), aldolase, LDH, AST/ALT
    • Autoantibodies:
      • May include anti-Jo-1 or other myositis-specific antibodies
    • Electromyography (EMG):
      • Shows myopathic changes
    • Muscle biopsy:
      • Confirms diagnosis; shows inflammation, fiber necrosis, and perifascicular atrophy
  • Treatment Approach:
    • First-line:
      • Systemic corticosteroids
    • Steroid-sparing agents:
      • Methotrexate, azathioprine
    • For refractory/severe cases:
      • IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin)
    • Supportive care:
      • Physiotherapy and monitoring for complications (e.g., calcinosis, vasculopathy)

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): Rheumatoid nodules are firm, non-tender subcutaneous swellings typically over extensor surfaces like the elbows and are not scaly or erythematous. They lack the violaceous discoloration and distribution over knuckles seen with Gottron's papules.


Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis (Option C): Sclerodactyly presents with tight, thickened, shiny skin over the fingers and is often associated with Raynaud's phenomenon. It does not produce scaly plaques or papules on the knuckles.


Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D): Mechanic's hands show hyperkeratotic, fissured skin on palms and fingers, associated with antisynthetase syndrome, not SLE. Additionally, the knuckle involvement seen here is more typical of Gottron's papules.

choices.text: Stop MDT and start oral steroids
Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.text: A 12-week pregnant woman undergoing multidrug therapy (MDT) for multibacillary leprosy presents with fever, painful erythematous nodules on her limbs, and general malaise. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario suggests erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), a type 2 lepra reaction, which is a type III hypersensitivity response seen in multibacillary leprosy. The recommended treatment during pregnancy is to continue MDT and add oral corticosteroids.

Type 2 Lepra Reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL):

  • Hypersensitivity Type: Immune complex-mediated (Type III hypersensitivity).
  • Cause: Reaction to antigens from Mycobacterium leprae.
  • Pathology: Neutrophilic vasculitis due to deposition of immune complexes.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cutaneous: Painful, erythematous nodules (may ulcerate).
    • Systemic: Fever, malaise, asthenia.
    • Other Organ Involvement:
      • Nerves: Neuritis
      • Joints: Arthritis, synovitis
      • Eyes: Iridocyclitis
      • Testes: Epididymo-orchitis
      • Liver & Kidneys: Hepatitis, glomerulonephritis
      • Lymphatics: Lymphadenopathy
  • Management:
    • Continue MDT: Essential to prevent relapse, even during reaction.
    • First-line treatment: Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) - safe in pregnancy.
    • Supportive care: Analgesics, wound care for ulcerated lesions.
    • Drugs to Avoid in Pregnancy: Thalidomide (Option C) - Teratogenic, associated with severe congenital anomalies like phocomelia.

Explanation of other options:

Stop MDT and start oral steroids (Option A): Stopping MDT during a type 2 lepra reaction is not recommended, as it may worsen the underlying leprosy and increase the risk of relapse. MDT should be continued, with steroids added to control the immune-mediated inflammation.

Antibiotics (Option B): ENL is an immune-mediated reaction, not a bacterial infection. Antibiotics are ineffective for ENL and do not address the underlying hypersensitivity.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8749206/

questions.text: A child presents with hair loss and an itchy, inflamed patch on the scalp, as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of scalp itching and hair loss, along with the image showing a scaly, inflamed, well-demarcated lesion, points toward a diagnosis of Tinea capitis. The most appropriate initial investigation in this case is a KOH mount, which helps visualize fungal hyphae in affected hair shafts or skin scales.


Tinea Capitis:

  • Etiology:
    • Caused by dermatophytes: Trichophyton and Microsporum species.
    • More common in children, especially in hot and humid climates.
  • Clinical Types:
    • Non-inflammatory:
      • Presents as scaly patches with black dots or broken hairs.
    • Inflammatory (Kerion):
      • Painful, boggy swelling with pustules and crusting (may resemble an abscess).
  • Diagnosis:
    • KOH mount: Reveals fungal elements in hair or skin scrapings.
    • Fungal culture: Confirms species.
    • Wood’s lamp: Shows green fluorescence in Microsporum infections.
  • Treatment:
    • Oral antifungals: Griseofulvin or Terbinafine for 6-8 weeks (essential for cure).
    • Adjunct shampoos: Ketoconazole or selenium sulfide to reduce transmission.
    • Kerion cases: May require systemic corticosteroids to control inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Slit Skin Smear (Option B): Used primarily to diagnose leprosy by detecting acid-fast bacilli in skin lesions; it has no role in diagnosing fungal scalp infections like tinea capitis.

Gram Stain (Option C): Used to detect bacterial organisms in skin infections; it cannot identify dermatophyte fungi responsible for tinea capitis.

Skin Biopsy (Option D): A more invasive test reserved for unclear or atypical cases; it is not the first-line investigation in straightforward cases of suspected fungal scalp infection.

questions.text: The following patient came with history of hair loss. There were no complaints of erythema, scarring and scratching. The dermoscopy image of the patient is shown below.Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hair pulling tic, OCD
  • Young patient pull out own hair
  • Defined as the irresistible urge to pull out hair, accompanied by a sense of relief after it has been plucked
  • Alopecia patch with hair of different length in different directions
  • Broken hair with perifollicular haemorrhage also seen

questions.text: An 8-month old child presented with itchy lesions as shown in image. The siblings also have similar complaints. The treatment of choice is such a patient is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child in this question indicates features of scabies caused because of Sarcoptesscabei. Treatment of choice in scabies is 5% permethrin cream. In adults, its application is usually from the neck down and after 8 to 14 hours of application it is washed off. In children less than 5 years of age and even the elderly, this cream should be applied on the entire skin surface except the eyes. Some other treatment options are also there, such as:

  • 10% Topical crotominton
  • 1% gamma benzene hexachloride
  • 25% Benzyl benzoate
  • Ivermectin

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with multiple episodes of GTCS was prescribed phenytoin by district hospital physician. After 7 days she presents with a single skin lesion on her arm as shown below. Which of the following will predispose to the condition shown here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a circular lesion with peripheral erythematous halo after start of anti-epileptic drugs. This is a fixed drug eruption.
  • HLA B1502 allele predisposes to reactions to anticonvulsants HLA B5801 allele predisposes to serious reactions to allopurinol.
  • Fixed drug eruption lesion will reappear at same site after re-administration of drug apart from new ones developing at other sites.

They have a self-limiting course
